content:
Perhaps too simple? Overall, the app does let me set an alarm on my scooter, unlocked the higher speed, and actually I appreciate the brief riders safety course. Sure, I know I ought to wear a helmet and protection, but it sets the vibe that Segway/Ninebot users are likely to be a little more safety conscious.

As far as the scooter itself goes, mine is a Walmart version D18W. It owes its 30 lbs weight to the smaller battery capacity‚Ä¶ to be able to ride up the obnoxiously steep hill by my house AND keep up with car traffic (no sidewalk), I would need a drastically more powerful scooter, one which would be too heavy to practically carry up steps (or the hill if it only was able to reach 5mph faster top speed). 15mph is honestly as fast as I want to go when I occasionally have to go over cracks, and I can still make a round trip to a cafe and a grocery store before heading back home on one charge (1 mile battery to spare). I don‚Äôt feel at all like the scooter will shoot out from under me like my eSkateboard has done, and it seems to absorb bumps and cracks as well as my bike. Grey is a little boring, but I have to admit it looks sleek.

The app has some pros and cons. It‚Äôs still a 5-star review, because the app lets me do what I want to do, is easy to arm the alarm and track the scoot, enable walking mode (wish I could enable this from the scooter itself, without a phone), and the eBrake takes a little getting used to but then I need to use the drum break much less. The con is that it doesn‚Äôt seem easy to use the community features‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs a points reward system, which is cool, but it talks about posting comments and reviews, and I don‚Äôt see how to do that from the main screen, profile, or ‚Äúhomepage.‚Äù So I‚Äôll probably never earn enough reward points to mean anything üòÖ. Hard to use bonus features aside, the core function is good and hasn‚Äôt glitched on me.

Overall, unlike my skateboard, I finally feel like I have my first EV and a decent ‚Äúlast mile‚Äù solution. I wouldn‚Äôt want anything heavier, and for something faster I would rather have a seated moped scooter that can ride on the street with traffic (so, with hills, I would need a scooter that could hit 35 mph on a 25¬∞ incline to be safe among car traffic). The app works fine, this scooter comes with me into the house and stores just fine, and I‚Äôm happy with it :)
